description: From Middle English clernesse; equivalent to clear +‎ -ness.

entries.meaning: Mental or sensory distinctness; clarity of understanding, perception etc. [from 16th c.]
examples: The daily press is the evil principle of the modern world, and time will only serve to disclose this fact with greater and greater clearness.

entries.meaning: The state of being free from obscurities or opacity; distinctness of light, colour etc. [from 17th c.]
examples: The clearness of the water meant I could still see the key lying on the river-bed.

entries.meaning: The state of being free from obstruction or interference. [from 17th c.]
examples: The clearness of the path made for an easy hike.
